Point P is located at (2 comma 0) and is labeled Start.

The circle passes through the following points with coordinates:

(2 comma 0)

(0 comma 2)

(negative 2 comma 0)

(0 comma negative 2)

Arrows on the circle indicate a counterclockwise direction of rotation.

A large wheel of radius <math alttext="2"><semantics><mn>2</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> feet is rotated at a constant rate. The figure provides a representation of the wheel in the <math alttext="x y"> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> <mi>y</mi> </mrow> <annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation> </semantics> </math>-plane with the direction of rotation indicated. At time <math alttext="t equals 0"><semantics><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> minutes, the wheel begins to rotate. Point <math alttext="P"><semantics><mi>P</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> on the wheel is at the “Start” position in the figure. At time <math alttext="t equals 20"><semantics><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> minutes, <math alttext="120"><semantics><mn>120</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> rotations of the wheel have been completed, and <math alttext="P"> <semantics> <mi>P</mi> <annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation> </semantics> </math> is in the same position as it was at time <math alttext="t equals 0"><semantics><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>. A sinusoidal function is used to model the <math alttext="y"><semantics><mi>y</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>-coordinate of the position of <math alttext="P"><semantics><mi>P</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> as a function of time <math alttext="t"><semantics><mi>t</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> in minutes.
content.question: Which of the following functions is an appropriate model for this situation?
